content.webTitle: Can the Melbourne Cup stop a city just starting up again?

fields.headline: Can the Melbourne Cup stop a city just starting up again?
fields.bodyText: There will be no roar as the Melbourne Cup field turns into the straight. No tweets from the Bird Cage. And not even a protest at the gates of Flemington. It might be the race that stops the nation, but how will the cup stop a city that only just started up again? “I’m still going to get dressed up,” Melbourne milliner Natalie Bikicki told Guardian Australia. “I’ll put a hat on my son, get dressed up and head down to the local park for a picnic and some champagne. “I’ll watch the race. I really like the energy of it, so I’ll have to watch it live.” Normally Bikicki is off her feet this time of year. She would attend cup day as a guest in a salubrious marquee, and is usually called upon to judge fashion awards on one of the other major race days. But in March, with Covid-19 sweeping through Europe, she predicted it would not be the usual spring racing carnival. Sales are down, but interstate clients have ordered many more hats than previously, and Bikicki is grateful that the Melbourne Cup carnival still held millinery awards, despite the lack of crowds. She is one of 10 finalists in the awards, with her creation symbolising an antidote to the pandemic: a heart exploding with joy. “I’d normally be so stacked, I wouldn’t have answered the phone,” Bikicki says. “I kind of had a disconcerting feeling this would be a long haul. I was just looking at the global situation and seeing that we’d been trickling behind. “It’s lovely to [still] be part of it. I’m so glad they’re having the millinery awards. It was a lovely distraction and challenge.” The possibility of crowds at the cup was dashed late last month after the public backlash to the Andrews government’s plan to allow owners on track for the Cox Plate – the government reneged on the plan as a result. There will be events to mark the day across the nation, from the Sydney Opera House to the Darwin turf club. But you’d be hard-pressed to get a beer or watch the race in the three pubs closest to the finishing post, with Melbourne’s lockdown only lifting last week and retailers subject to strict opening conditions. Two of the pubs on Racecourse Road, Flemington, will be closed when the race is run. The third, The Newmarket, isn’t taking bookings and can only have a maximum of 10 people in each of its indoor areas. The furthest pub from the track on Racecourse Road, The Quiet Man, has been fully booked for 70 people since last Monday. But it doesn’t open until 4pm – an hour after the race starts. “That’s just our normal opening hours on a Tuesday,” a spokesman for the pub said. The Coalition for the Protection of Racehorses has cancelled its usual protest on the morning of the race in favour of a virtual event and is selling “Nup to the Cup” face masks. It protested at the Flemington gates on Monday with People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, and will hold a small meeting at a nearby park. “We may not be able to host our usual ‘in real life’ picnic and protest this year, but we can still protest the cruel Melbourne Cup from wherever else we may be on this day,” the group posted online. “As a statement against animal abuse, please take a photo of yourself wearing your ... ‘Nup to the Cup’ face mask, or if you prefer, simply hold a sign stating ‘Say Nup to the Cup’ and post it on all of your social media pages at, or as close to 9am as possible on the morning of the Melbourne Cup. “Let’s ensure social media is flooded with messages of kindness for horses, not cruelty.” Kristin Leigh, a spokeswoman for the Coalition for the Protection of Racehorses, said she was hoping the pause in crowds could mean the cup becomes less relevant this year. The group is also planning to hijack social media posts relating to “fashions on the front lawn”, which have replaced “fashions on the field” this year and drawn entries from across Australia. But perhaps the biggest impediment to Melbourne engaging with the cup will be the forecast of spring sunshine, coming only a week after the end of more than three months in lockdown. Melbourne is forecast to nudge 30C on Tuesday afternoon, meaning it could be the warmest day since March – weather more conducive to the beach or the park, rather than perched in front of a television watching a horse race. Police are expected to patrol public areas to ensure no breaches of the chief health officer’s restrictions.
